clinical_study.brief_title: Study of High Flow Nasal Cannula Oxygen for Bronchoscopy With Bronchoalveolar Lavage in ICU Patients
clinical_study.official_title: High Flow Nasal Oxygen for Bronchoscopy With Bronchoalveolar Lavage in Acute Respiratory Failure Patients: the OptiBAL Study.

brief_summary.textblock: Bronchoscopy with bronchoalveolar lavage (BAL) is at risk for worsening hypoxemia in patients with acute respiratory failure (ARF). High-flow nasal cannula oxygen (HFNC) improves hypoxemia in ARF patients . We investigated its efficacy and tolerance in intensive care unit patients admitted for ARF requiring BAL.

detailed_description.textblock: Prospective, observational, multicenter study in ARF patients (minimal pulse oximetry -SpO2- of 92% with an minimal oxygen flow of 6 L/min , respiratory rate > 25/min (20/min if use of accessory respiratory muscles) with a compatible etiology. Primary outcome measure is increase in ventilatory support (non-invasive positive pressure ventilation (NPPV) or endotracheal intubation (ETI)) within the first 24h following BAL.

primary_outcome.description: increase in ventilatory support (non-invasive positive pressure ventilation (NPPV) or endotracheal intubation (ETI)) within the first 24h following BAL

secondary_outcome.measure: Immediate tolerance of bronchoscopy and BAL

secondary_outcome.description: Physician performing the BAL procedure rated their comfort with HFNC from 0 to 10

arm_group.description: Adult ARF ICU patients needing BAL with HFNC

intervention.intervention_name: Adult ARF ICU patients needing BAL with HFNC
intervention.description: bronchoalveolar lavage is performed in spontaneously breathing patients under high flow nasal cannula oxygen

study_pop.textblock: Adult patients admitted to the Intensive Care Unit, with acute hypoxemic respiratory failure requiring bronchoalveolar lavage

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:
- presence of acute respiratory failure: defined as respiratory rate greater than 25/min, (or greater than 20/min if use of accessory respiratory muscles was present), in patients requiring oxygen greater than or equal to 6 L/min to obtain a pulse oximetry greater than 92%
- need for bronchoalveolar lavage (decision to perform BAL was left at the physician's discretion)
Exclusion Criteria:
- at least one contraindication to the bronchoscopy with BAL: acute coronary syndrome within 6 weeks; neurologic failure; thrombocytopenia less than 30 000/mm3; respiratory acidosis with a pH lower than 7.30 or hypercapnia higher than 60 mmHg; pneumothorax undrained.
